awd_titl_txt: RUI:   Apoplastic lipids in xylem of vascular plants:   Composition, locations, origins, and possible functions
awd_abstract_narration:
Vascular plants are the only organisms known to transport water under negative pressure, using solar energy to create the force for moving water from soil to roots to leaves and out into the atmosphere. How plants can do this without constantly creating bubbles in their hydraulic systems, which act to block the water transport is still not completely understood. Engineers have not been able to replicate water transport under negative pressure, except in very small amounts over very short distances under idealized laboratory conditions.  So how can trees move vast quantities of water through the xylem (wood) in their trunks under negative pressure? The goal of this research is to determine the role of natural oils (lipids) in this process. Lipids have been found covering the surfaces of xylem vessels in plants. The project will determine the composition, locations, origins, and possible functions of lipids in xylem of vascular plants and test the hypothesis that lipids are required for negative pressure transport. The research will increase the understanding of plant adaptation to water stress, and could potentially lead to engineered systems that replicate plant water transport under negative pressure. The research will involve undergraduate students, including from groups currently underrepresented in the sciences, and its broader impacts will include education about plant water transport both in academic courses and public outreach events.

It has been an axiom of the cohesion-tension theory that it is the high surface tension of water that protects xylem conduits against bubble entry. This axiom was recently challenged by findings that xylem sap of flowering plants contains significant amounts of surface-active lipids and that surfactants isolated from xylem sap strongly reduced the sap's surface tension. Moreover, surfactant-coated bubbles were found in sap, suggesting that plants can transport water in the presence of bubbles, rather than needing to prevent their formation completely. This research addresses the questions: 1. Are apoplastic lipids found in xylem of all major groups of vascular plants? 2. What is the composition of apoplastic lipids in different plants? 3. Where in the xylem are apoplastic lipids located? 4. Where do apoplastic xylem lipids originate? The research will use 15 representative species of all major vascular plant lineages using imaging via TEM, confocal super-resolution microscopy, atomic force microscopy, and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, as well as by lipidomic analyses of xylem sap and xylem tissue using mass spectrometry. The research will test the paradigm-reversing hypothesis that lipid-coatings of gas-water surfaces provide the hydraulic system with a degree of protection against bubbles expanding into embolism and causing hydraulic failure. The proposed research on lipids in water under negative pressure will contribute to scientific knowledge not only in plant biology, but also in physics and chemical engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits:

In previous NSF-funded research, we had found that xylem sap of woody angiosperms contains polar lipids, such as phospholipids and galactolipids, and that these lipids coat most surfaces in the non-living conduits of the xylem, including vessels and tracheids, a space known as the xylem apoplast. The major goals of this project were to answer the following questions: 1. Are apoplastic lipids found in xylem of all major groups of vascular plants? 2. What is the composition of apoplastic lipids in different plants? 3. Where in the xylem are apoplastic lipids located? 4. Where do apoplastic xylem lipids originate? 5. What are the possible functions of apoplastic lipids?

Apoplastic xylem lipids were studied in 18 plants species, spanning most major groups of vascular plants, including 12 angiosperms (9 Dicots and 3 Monocots) and six gymnosperms (three conifers, two gnetophytes, and ginkgo). Five additional angiosperms were studied in related research in the lab of co-PI Steven Jansen. All plants studied contained apoplastic xylem lipids. Plants with tracheids had consistently much lower lipid concentrations than plants with vessels, a fact that was explained by a filtering effect: Polar lipids form micelles or coat nanobubbles, and these are too large to move from one xylem conduit to the next, because the small pores of pit membranes between the conduits do not allow such large objects to pass. Therefore polar lipids are not transported with the sap towards the leaves.

All xylem sap lipids contained both phospholipids and galactolipids, plus varying degrees of neutral lipids, with a high concentrations of triacylglycerides in a few species. Only traces of sulfolipids were found in a few species. Differences in xylem lipidomics between species were found to be closely related to phylogeny. Lipids were detected on the interior surfaces of xylem conduits, including vessels and tracheids, and in bordered pits between conduits, including coatings on pit membranes and inside pit membrane pores. Conifers generally had smaller amounts of xylem lipids than angiosperms.

We found no evidence for transport of lipids from living cell into vessels when using electron microscopy to image locations where living cells border on vessels. Comparing lipids in cells at various stages of xylem development supported previous findings that lipids remain in cells when all other cell components are enzymatically removed during conduit maturation. The chemical composition of lipids in xylem sap was very similar to the composition of lipids in whole xylem, including the living cells, indicating that xylem sap lipids originate from the living cell content and remain in conduits after the other cell content has been removed during cell death.

In experiments with an artificial system designed to mimic hydraulic conductance through cellulosic pit membranes, presence of polar lipids did not affect hydraulic conductance in the presence of different KCl concentrations. Using drying PDMS gels to create negative pressure in embedded droplets of water with or without polar lipids, we found no effect of lipids on the duration to the formation of visible bubbles (i.e., embolism) or the pressure at which these bubbles formed. Molecular dynamics simulations also led to the conclusion that micelles and bilayers of polar lipids in xylem do not cavitate above negative pressures of about -10 MPa, i.e., not at pressures normally found in plants. Despite their effect on lowering surface tension, polar lipids do not increase the vulnerability to gas bubble formation in water nor do they decrease that vulnerability.

In summary, our research findings provided abundant evidence for the existence of apoplastic polar lipids in the xylem of vascular plants, as well as the existence of polar-lipid-coated nanobubbles in the xylem of flowering plants. Going forward, the disciplines of plant physiology and plant ecophysiology must account for the existence of polar lipids and lipid-coated nanobubbles in xylem, leading to a reevaluation of previous assumptions about the origins of gas bubble formation in vascular plants under drought stress.

Broader Impacts

The project provided opportunities for research and teaching for the PI and co-PIs as well as a postdoc, improved the performance, skills, or attitudes of several members of underrepresented groups, and provided exposure to science and technology for all students who were involved in this research. This included seven graduate students, including one student from a group that is underrepresented in STEM fields. Ten undergraduate students were actively involved in the research, including four from groups that are underrepresented in STEM fields. Equipment and materials purchased for the project continue to be used for teaching lab modules of courses taught by the PI, including plant physiological ecology and global change biology, where research findings and research approaches are shared with undergraduate and graduate students at California State University Fullerton.
